Key Arguments: The legislation infringes on inalienable human rights and freedom of expression as outlined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Article 19.
The government should not control speech through threats of punishment; instead, people should be educated in Natural Law.
The ACMA lacks the qualifications to judge truthfulness and potential harm, which could lead to tyranny.
The Bill exempts certain entities, including the government, from accountability, which could lead to harm.
The Bill could be applied to private messaging, threatening personal communications.
Existing laws already address harm caused by communication, making this Bill unnecessary.
The Bill could stifle societal growth and development by restricting communication.
The Bill lacks a lawful basis under the Commonwealth Constitution.
Notable Quotes: To restrict in any way the free expression, discussion and interaction of ideas and opinions is to restrict the development of mankind.
ACMA is not God nor an expert with the final say on all matters concerning the human situation.
The result is effectively enslavement of the people.
It is MY WILL that this Bill shall be rejected in total. I do not consent to this Bill becoming an Act in any form.
